media.description:
The Words That Make The Threads

Nairaland is a popular online forum where youths give their opinions on wide array of topics that are usually called threads posted by the forum members. They are organized into different sections including Politics, Business, Crime, Sports, Travel, Investment, Jobs/Vacancies, Programming, Sports, Celebrities, etc.
I collected 28,800 threads posted between 31st May, 2019 and 2nd of June, 2020,courtesy of a fellow Nairalander, then made them into wordclouds. The first wordcloud shows the sections by the number of threads created in each, and it was revealed that Politics gets more posts than any other sections on the forum.
The 3 most popular section on Nairaland are #Politics, #Celebrities and #Crime as revealed in the first visual. This shows just how much we enjoy talking about politics, celebrities, and the spate of crime in Nigeria.
The second wordcloud shows the frequency of words used in the titles of the threads created within those periods. 
Enjoy!
Akerele Oluwasogo, GLMP Ahmed Oyelowo (MVP, MCSA, MCT, AFM) Adewale Yusuf (MVP, MCSA, MCDA, MCT) Zainab Balogun Mediat Yusuff Precious Oladipo Tolulope 

#dataanalytics #powerbi #datavisualization #design #wordcloud

media.description:
But just what is Power BI?

Power BI which stands for Power Business Intelligence, is a software tool from the stable of Microsoft Corporation. 
It's a software program for data analytics and data science.
If you have used Microsoft Excel or are using Microsoft Excel, then you will get comfortable with Power BI in no time.
It's functionalities surpass that of Excel though.
It is an integration of the Power Apps including Power Query (Michael Olafusi will call this data washing machine), Power Pivot, Power View, and Power Map.
Power BI allows you to explore the possibility of these apps at a go.

title: Ibikunle Gabriel wrote on Lizzy Lord's timeline.

data.post:
Remembering people's names is a vital but underrated interpersonal skill. Napoleon Bonaparte had a knack for remembering his soldiers' names and that earned him more respect among the army. 
I remembered earlier this year when I met a friend after a long time. She has a friend and they are always together. I knew the names of both of them. When I saw them I greeted her. Hey, Olufunmi Abiola Brown how are you? Been a while. Then it was time for me to acknowledge her friend. I wanted to call her name, and guess what? I went blank. Then I courteously asked. Could you please remind me of your name? She replied: Wow you remembered my friend's full name? Full name, and you didn't remember mine. I'm not telling you. I felt bad. So I promised myself I was going to remember her full name next time which I did.
People's names sounds sweet to their hearings and it shows you're thoughtful!

data.post:
On School, Success, and Suicide

During one of our breaks, a neighbour of mine told me in one of our conversations:
âIf you know anybody who is studying something related to chemicals they use in factories, tell him to face his book well, there is money in it o.â
âThatâs Industrial Chemistryâ, I offered.
âYes, Iâm working in one company like that. We help them to offload the chemicals they use in the production of household goods. Itâs the workers who are educated among us that are earning the most. In fact Iâm now regretting not going to school. I will ensure this my two kids go as far as possible in their education.â He was misty-eyed as he told me this.
In the midst of our talk, the thought of my roommate, Seun whom we popularly call Gomi came to my mind. He was an Industrial Chemistry student. Quite intelligent, always raising topics that relate to Polypeptides, Acrylic, Carbolic Acid, Ethanol and the rest. Sometimes, he asked us why we think itâs necessary to spritz water on cloth before pressing it. And then he would go ahead to explain.
The guy, we were told was already working in a paint industry soon after his graduation. Thatâs before going for Service.
Sometimes, we cannot disconnect success from schooling.
What I have observed is, those who say: âSchool na scamâ are those who have had a connection with school. A stark illiterate does not understand the meaning of scam, let alone using it to describe an eye-opening institution like school.
People make statement like that because they place high hope on school, but are disillusioned at the end of the day. Not as rosy as they expect it to be. 
The fact is we must demand more of ourselves than from any school system. The society that created the formula: âgo to school, get the certificate, look for a job and start a lifeâ needs to be told that this is now anachronistic. Pick up a copy of Stop Killing Dreams by Seth Godin, or Rich Dad, Poor Dad by Robert Kiyosaki to get the hang of what Iâm saying.
Bill gates has read more books than some graduates, Seun Osewa of Nairaland has put more powerful thoughts to paper, and more contents online  than some of our graduates. Both have made impacts in their respective domains, and it makes me wonder: Who is really the drop out?
In the last few years many Nigerian youths have committed suicide for several reasons ranging from academic failure, jilting and disappointment which leads to depression and then, the inevitable.
It is said that the last thing to leave a man is hope. As humans, we must be wise enough not to build our hope around just a single entity.
Sometimes, I wonder if a black hat hacker needs a certificate to hack down a whole system, or if a lady will still not see another man after a man kills himself because of her. 
For anybody contemplating suicide, please understand that disappointment in any area is not the end of the world. Suicide is an unceremonious bravery and hence, itâs never an option. You can always rise again. I will leave you with the words of Rancho to Farhan in the movie, 3 Idiots: âIf suicide ever cross your mind, take the picture of your parents and think of what will happen to those smiles if you do it.

Â©IBK

data.post:
The election was a landslide. We were allowed to witness the counting of the votes. So an assembly of students was called for the announcement of the winners. I remember some students telling me jokingly not to walk alone so that they will not kidnap me, because itâs certain that Iâd won.
Students were gathered together on the assembly ground eagerly waiting for the outcome of the poll, when suddenly it was announced that the winners will no longer be announced that soon, and that the students should go back to their respective classes. 
It was my principal that gave the order to disperse the assembly. She obviously was still skeptical about my ability to control the students. I understood her fear, it was a public school where we had scores of students who were extremely stubborn and crude in manners. Our set came up in the wake of the era when students come to school with weapons such as the legendary âLebeâ because inter-school feud was common then. That was minimal in our set, but we still had students who were unruly.
It was during the first term in SS3 that they officially announced our respective posts. My joy knew no bounds when I was called upon last and decorated with the badge of the head boy. I remembered Sapele Otega and a friend of his bearing me shoulder high to the assembly platform. 
Looking back, I learnt from that memory that if you should do something, do it, even if the odds are against you.

title: Ibikunle Gabriel updated his status.

data.post:
Childhood Reminiscence 2 Contâd
Four of us, Omaka Kingsley(whom we graduated together in university), Victor Eyoh, Okuntade Ademola and me contested in the election for the post of the senior prefect. The election was overseen by Mr Jaiyeola, an intelligent science teacher who likes me a lot and must have defended me at the presence of the principal several times. He never doubted my ability and charisma. He'd  earlier had a meeting with the 120 of us that were selected as acting prefects. During the meeting, heâd asked us, âWho among you thinks he can be the head boy of this school?â There was a pregnant silence in the hall. Again he said, âIf you think you can be the head boy of this school, stand up.â I moved unnoticeably to the edge of my seat, and in that instant I felt a hand touching me from behind, and someone telling me, âStand up, you can do it.â It was Sunday Okegbola. I stood up, looked behind me(I was seated at the front), and saw one more person on his feet. It was Ademola. Mr Jaiyeola then decided to make me the supervisor, and asked Ademola to be my assistant.
On the day of our manifesto declarations, I overheard a female colleague from art class saying, âIbikunle will not become our head boy, I just donât like him,  I can even say it to his face.â She was at the entrance of the class we used for the manifesto declarations, and when we came out from the class. She hit my chest gently and rhythmically, muttering âYou will not be our head boyâ. I just smiled and went away with crowd of supporters behind me. I remember some of the students saying donât mind her, you will be our head boy.

title: Ibikunle Gabriel updated his status.

data.post:
Childhood Reminiscence 2
âIbikunle what post do you want us to give you?â Mrs Enilololobo, my school principal asked me after her usual morning prayer walking round the school premises. We were usually the first two persons to arrive at school. Itâs either she arrived before me or the other way round.
âHeadboy maâ, I replied staring at the ground.
âYou canât be the head boy of this schoolâ, she said while being straight faced
âBut why ma, I asked wrinkling my forehead and scratching my head at the same time.
âWell, the reason is you are too friendly with your junior colleagues and classmates alike, I doubt if they they will have a spark of respect for you, and we canât leave anything to chance; you know how stubborn the students of this school are.â
She went up to her office after the conversation. I walked away gloomily. I knew her well enough to understand she meant what she had said. She had a no-nonsense personality, only few students including me and Sapele Otega, who was quite influential and was supposedly her church member had the luxury of entering her office for one reason or the other.

title: Ibikunle Gabriel updated his status.

data.post:
Campus Reminiscence 1 Contâd

Suddenly, a group of students shouted, âwon ti de o, awon cultistsâ.  Everybody started running helter-skelter. The situation was compounded by the fear of the dÃ©jÃ  vu of the 1999 gory incident. A student even jumped down on the concrete hallway from the Upper Buttery about 9 feet high, badly injuring himself. Distracted by the bag I left where I sat earlier, I totally forgot I was with someone. I went for the bag and then joined the stampede. Few seconds later, I came back to my senses and head back towards the Cafe to look for Lewa. Fortunately for me, I saw her seeking refuge behind the photocopiersâ stands at the Cafe. So I took her hand, and accompanied her towards her hostel until we were both sure itâs safe for her to walk down alone to the hostel. Moment later, I felt like oh thank goodness I saw  Lewa when I returned to look for her. She might have told me, â see you, you couldnât even protect me and you want to date meâ.

title: Ibikunle Gabriel posted in Relationship/Inspirational Tips by Rev'd Oluwamurewa Oluwanifemi.

data.post:
Campus Reminiscence 1

 I was heading back to my hostel from Academics as usual. So on getting to Awo Hall, I decided to enter Awo Cafe to catch some chills. I sat on a chair, then dropped my bag on the reading table. In that instant I sighted Lewa my friend and crush on one of the chairs far away from mine, studying. Leaving my bag, I went close and took my seat beside her. We began to chat as usual. At the same time, the politikoko guys were deliberating on hot campus political matters. The whole place was uncontrollably boisterous. Theyâd started their deliberations even before I came around, but I was not too surprised Lewa could cope with such hell of a noise. 
That is the nature of Awo Cafe. It is a market place, where students face what ever they came to buy or sell. Some students may be reading at a section of the Cafe, while some others chit-chat at another section. It is not uncommon to see clownish students make their way into the Cafe and suddenly throw jibes that left some students distracted and some others indifferent. Some handshakes and laughter among friends were just loud enough to attract the attention of every living being present at that moment.
On this particular night, the atmosphere was tense in the Cafe. The vociferation was unbearable, so only few students were reading there. There was a dissension among the student union leaders, and theyâd chosen Awo Cafe as the ground for flexing their muscles. The argument among them was gaining momentum until it reached a fearsome crescendo.

title: Ibikunle Gabriel wrote on Qudus Adesegun Fatau's timeline.

data.post:
CHILDHOOD REMINISCENCE 1

On a particular day in the year 2006, then still in the junior secondary school, I offended my mother, so she threatened not to give me pocket money for school that day until I do what she had asked me to do. So, I decided to âpunishâ her, with the sheer ignorance of the fact that I was doing myself a disfavour. For the first and last time in my life I played truancy. Unfortunately for me, our neighbour who was going out saw me at the time of the day no serious students should be seen gallivanting around, and reported me at home. Worse still, I got home earlier than I should that dayâI miscalculated the closing time, because I was feeling either homesick or schoolsick already. Before I got home, the storm was already waiting for me, ready to break. 
 On getting home, they went through my books and saw that the latest date on my notes was the date of a day two weeks back. My mother and our neighbours began to tongue-lash me. In that instant, one of my land lordâs sons who is known to be a disciplinarian asked me to start smoking Monkey Cigarette (thatâs a kind of punishment), and then went inside to take his belt in order to give me the beating of my life.
 I was an ardent football fan, and it was during the 2006 FIFA World Cup hosted by Germany.  As I was observing the punishment, I remembered Brazil will be playing Japan that day and once he beat me I wouldnât be able to go out and watch the match, as that would further confirm my stubbornness and lack of seriousness to everybody around. I saw him through the window as he was coming outside from his room with a black belt in his hand. In that instant, barefooted, I whizzed out of the compound, and ran away in the presence of everyone around, then went to a viewing centre located streets away from our house to enjoy the match. They were looking for me all day around the vicinity. I returned home only when it was dark, so nobody was talking about scolding me again. I was served a delicious meal. I remembered my land lordâs son vowing not to ever intervene in my issues again. 
Days later I was with this my land lordâs son in his room. Being an ardent football fan himself, we were both watching our Super Falcons players being granted an interview ahead of a tournament. Then suddenly he turned to me and said, âThe other day, you didnât get to school, I wanted to chastise you; you ran away. Look at those female footballers on the television right now, they are speaking correct Englishâ¦ and weâre impressed right? If eventually you become a footballer, they interview you, and  can't  speak correct English, what becomes of you?â 
From that day onward, I decided to turn a new leaf, and looking back all the years, I was glad I did turn that new leaf.

data.post:
The Rest Room and the Million Naira Idea

Ideas, it is said rule the world. Large establishments today began as lean startups and each lean startup began as a single idea. Many thoughts and ideas flicker in our minds every day, but we hardly pay attention to them. These thoughts have a short life span, this is because human mind according to sages is like a monkey that hops freely from one tree to another. More than 600 thoughts cross our minds daily. We think without thinking! According to John C. Maxwell, ideas have a short shelf life. 
Ideas come to us just anywhere at any time, and the rest room is not an exception. I know someone who starts singing just immediately she enters the shower. Thatâs simply because inspiration flows to her right there. A colleague jokingly told us once that during exam times, he takes his jotters and key points with him into the rest room; he said he assimilates there better. That sounds awkward to some people, but the fact is, the rest room is a place where numerous ideas flow to people. Itâs a place where people think about things they wouldnât have otherwise thought about elsewhere. Some learners also assimilate better there.
I personally do wonder also why inspirations flow to people in the rest room, until I heard Pastor Segun Obadje, the G.O. of Godâs Love Tabernacle, Ile Ife spoke extensively about relaxation and recreation. He said we think better, and inspirations flow to us in the rest room because we are better relaxed there, and we have only one business in thereâ to get the shit out! When we are in the rest room, we are shut out from the buzz of quotidian activities, making us to think undisturbed.  
Paying attention to even the slightest ideas that occur to you is tantamount to making headway into something tangible and rewarding, and leveraging on opportunities. So, when else you enter the rest room and an idea whirls into your head, document it because it might just be a million Naira idea that will shoot you out of obscurity and into stardom.
Â©IBK

data.post:
A Screw Driver and a Brain
I took my laptop to Computer Village, Ikeja one day for repair. As I was approaching the arena, I saw some guys standing at few metres away from each other and in each person's hand was a screw driver. On sighting me, one of them asked if I wanted to repair my system, and I replied in the affirmative.
He asked me to come with him. We went upstairs, and there he teamed up with one other guy to work on the laptop. They repaired the PC to my utmost satisfaction with just the screw driver I saw the first guy holding.
Then I thought to myself, âWith a screw driver and a brain, the world can be made a better place!

Â©IBK

data.post:
Beautiful Nonsense

If I am to write, gently gently
All that I am willing to write
About the  beautiful nonsenses
Condoned by this society
I may have to write epistles
Much more than did Apostle Paul
We hang the petty thieves
And celebrate the seasoned ones
Killing a form of art, maiming a way of life
Our girls with tender hearts in their tender age
Are being trafficked to heaven-knows- where
By the heaven-knows-whos
Making us pay a ransom of national dejection
Criminality is tagged political game
And forces one to ask
Who is winning, who is losing?
We claim to love democracy
Yet give it momentary baptism of fire
It must be really dogged
Doesn't it ever end?
This indigenous version of colonialism
The constant exposure to the shackles of mental slavery
The corruption-is-not-stealing attitude
And the many ado about fuility

IBK

data.post:
Corruption

A monster that refuses to die
A shame that lingers on
A menace to the society
Impenetrable to bullet
Immune to euthanasia
Insulated against electrocution
The root cause of our underdevelopment
It's sent our economy to ruination
And our saints to damnation
It stings like a bee
Spits venom like a viper
A biased steward that serves those
Who already have a belly full
Of the national cake
At the expense of the have-nots

A demon that possess our leaders
With no hope of exorcism
Now they preach capital influx
But practice capital flight
They preach unity
But finance disunity
They preach security
But mastermind insecurity

An incorrigible thief
That robs us of our integrity
Cart away our conscience
Defraud us of our unity
Loot our treasury
Deny us of our freedom
Pauperise the masses
Rob our leaders of their broad-minds
And replace it with myopic ones

IBK

data.post:
Uncaged Bird
Today, I had the instinct
Of an uncaged bird
I felt what an uncaged bird feels:
The feeling that I can fly
And the freedom to fly as I wish
So I decided to fly around the world
To explore its fulness
Not leaving out its emptiness
To explore its glamour
Without bias to its squalor
In the course of my traverse
I landed in the house of the poor
I beheld their pursuit of riches
I landed in the house of the cynics
I caught a full glimpse of their pessimism
I landed in the house of the oppressed
I saw their crave for freedom
I landed in the house of the greedy
I heard their never-ending melody
of "We want some more."

IBk

data.post:
Tomorrow It Shall All Be Gone

We feel the pain
We groan at it
With a raspy voice
And we detest it also
But we say to ourselves
Tomorrow it shall all be gone

We gird up our loins
To face what lies ahead of us
Doesn't the ant work in the summer?
And gather its food during harvest?
We feel the hot prick of tears in our eyes
But we say to ourselves
Tomorrow it shall all be gone

Nobody listens to our clamour
Nobody hears our silent scream
But we bear it all
And say to ourselves
Tomorrow it shall all be gone

The road seems endless
The journey ad infinitum
The pain is overwhelming
And the journey overbearing
But we endure them all
And say to ourselves
Tomorrow it shall all be gone

IBK
Dedicated to all members of Cognoscenti, the 2016/2017 accounting graduating set.

data.post:
As I sign out
"Everybody has a story to tell, a joke to share and a lesson to learn."- Unknown
                                 How The Journey Started
It has always been my childhood dream to attend the prestigious Obafemi Awolowo University, so, when I was offered admission to study Management and Accounting in this great citadel, my joy knew no bound. Although, not until ASUU completed a six-month strike were we called upon to resume as freshers.Upon resumption, we began to do the necessary registrations- faculty registration, departmental registration health centre registration and so on. 
Few days after the necessary registrations, lectures began. As a freshman, I couldn't wait to receive my first lecture- the first lecture we had was on History of Accounting in Acc 101 which was taught by Dr. Mrs Salawu at Law 209. After the lecture that evening, I trudge to my hostel alongside a coursemate, relishing the joy of being an undergraduate. 
                            My Days In Awo Hall
Through out my undergraduate days, I stayed in Awo Hall. Awo Hall is the most popular hall on OAU campus. Its nickname is "castle of great men". Some students refer to it as the capital of OAU. The hall is always a lively place, especially in the evening. The Awo Boyz All-Star never failed to entertain the students with their "Aro"; the political-conscious students did gather beside the notice board at the lower buttery to discuss political issues. Those were the days of Comrade Engels, Ibikunle, who was the students' union president in my part one days, Comrade Juwon, Levuz, Hon.Bright, Ojogbon, Olori, Comrade Azaro, Binzu,  Honourable TY,who later became the students'union president, Immanuel Kant, Hon.IBk. Also some students made funny sounds all around the hostel like barking, bleating, mewing, and crowing, to make people laugh.
Our room was often boisterous with guys arguing about sport, music, academics, politics, the opposite sex and many more. On many occasions, guys from other rooms came to our room to engage us in conversations about different topics. It's difficult to concentrate on reading in the room. If you wanted to read, you would have to pack your books and go to Awo Cafe, Upper Reading Room or better still Academics. In spite of the noise, I sometimes read in the room and my room mates would wonder how I was able to concentrate, but it's a condition I've got myself used to.
In my part one days an amazing incident happened in our room, which still amuses me to this day. It was around 2 a.m. and we were all asleep except for Alfa Shina who was washing his cloth downstairs. The whole drama began when Taiwo Suddenly sprang to his feet as if something had hit or a creature had bitten him. Quadri and Segun who slept beside him also woke up in that instant; the three of them headed for the door but before they got to the door, Modupe(Wandy) who had jumped down from his upper bunk was already there standing still.At that moment also, every other person including me was running  towards the door. I woke up when Daniel stamped on my feet while trying to make off. I was shouting: "Blood of Jesus!", "Blood of Jesus!!". If not for Modupe, a chubby guy who stood by the door motionless, Taiwo or Quadri would have succeeded in opening the door and some of us would have jumped down from our floor- the second floor- or probably rushed down through the staircase.
Soon after, we all came back to our senses and realised that there was no danger around; we didn't see any sign of fire, no strange movement or sound to make us think a snake had crept in, we asked Taiwo what he saw that made him spring to his feet in the first place, and he couldn't say anything. We laughed at ourselves for several days on this incident. 
                                     The Challenges
Anybody would agree to the fact that life in OAU  can be stressful. As an undergraduate, there were several challenges that came my way. After long hours of classes and tutorials, I have to still read (who wants to fail?). I refer to myself as a business student. Because even as a student, I have my own tutorial centre, I compiled past questions and solutions  on two courses, and most times I take private tutorials. Time is always a constraint. Lecturers will bombard you with materials on their respective courses.  I move from hostel to academics on average of four times in a day. During the time of political activities, close pals of mine going for the same post will walk up to me. "Ibk, I'm going for this, I'm going for that. " You have to decide on who to support. During breaks,  they will ask at home: "Who is the picture perfect? " 
                  Comics In The Midst Of Academic Rigours
In spite of all the academic rigours students face on campus, we would always have one or two things that amuse us students. In Awo Hall, we were often entertained by the Aro performance. Some hilarious guys could just enter into Awo Cafe and started throwing jibes at the students "jacking" there. On OAU campus, you may be referred to by your friends and course mates as "Shana" or "Iwe Ogba" even when you are still struggling with a course. On several occasions , I'd been to Academics to read, but found it difficult to concentrate, yet when coming back, my course mates I met on the way would still call me Iwe Ogba.
                         My Involvement In Political Activities
On gaining admission, I went to the secondary school I attended to break the news of my admission to my teachers, being a well recognised student in the school. One of them told me:
"Ibikunle, when you get to campus, don't join politics. Campus politics is bloody o, and don't join them in doing  any aluta o. You know you are tall, they can easily spot you."
Sincerely, I was glad OAU politics is not bloody compared to what I've heard about some other schools. I've joined the aluta train right from my day one on campus. I doff my cap for the comrades who fought frantically with their sweat and blood for the peace which OAU students now enjoy. Kudos to the comrades who from time to time defend the rights and interests of students. I have a lot of respect for these guys. 
I wanted to contest for the post of an honourable at the students' union level in my part 2 days, but as fate would have it, the students'union was suspended by the powers that be. In  my penultimate year, I contested for the post of the president in my department, but the best candidate won. My involvement in politics made me meet so many greatness-bound comrades who will forever be in my memory. I also learnt so many lessons politics has in stock to teach its students. I'm glad to have contributed my quota to the redefinition of the campus political terrain. 
                           The wonderful people I Met
In our sojourn in life, we'll come across many people God has chosen to be our companions as we journey on. I must not fail to mention the wonderful personalities I met in my short spell on this campus. Let me start from my wonderful lecturers like Mr. Quadri Lawal, a.k.a. Resolution whom I refer to as 'simple Resolution'(He has the most stupendous personality traits anyone can emulate or desire), Mr. Siyanbade a.k.a. I Can, Dr Monday, Dr. Olasanmi and other lecturers who've had significant impact in my life and career. 
I'll always relish the day I met Falade Adenike, an awesome companion anyone will dream of befriending. Olowu Oladipupo, you're a true friend. Tofunmi, you're a wonderful lady, Abiola, you're awesome, Wahab Akeem a.k.a. Highcomm, you're a rare gem. Omaka Kingsley, you're not just a friend, but also a mentor. I also appreciate The Cognoscentis, Olajide Oreoluwa a.k.a Pretty Priya, Oshun Adebola, Idowu Deborah, Taiwo, Kemi Helen, Esther, Bewaji Omolewa, Akerele Isaac, Emmanuel a.k.a. Pato(Law), Onuche (Law), Bernard P. Daniel,Paulo, Toluano(Phl), Papinx(LGS), Fiwajomi, Tosin, Adebisi, Essien, Funmilola, Pelumi, Rhoda (DSS), Ibidunmoye Decent Ayobami, Fynestboi (PHL), Bridget, Al-Ameen(Foreign Language), Deepeah (Pub Admin), Adefiranye Adenike, Ibukun (Interrel), Mimi, Gbemisola (History), Ife (Chm), E-Dan(Pharmacy),  Oluoma, Emmanuel Faith, Rachael (Econs Edu), Barezzi, Oyinda, Agnes, Hajia Rukayat, Wandy, Tbamz,Sinuola, Bimbo, Emperor, and every other person who made my campus sojourn memorable. 
                                                            And Finally
I always believe that the school made me. I'm confident to say I'm a product of sound formal and self education. I learnt a whole lot on this campus.To my junior colleagues, I will say: never lose the power of focus; never be a staight-jacketed kind of learners, don't limit yourselves to your field alone. Medical students write good poems. Explore your world. To my graduating course mates and colleagues, see you at the top
As I sign out today, I can gladly say:
Veni vedi vici

Sunmonu Ibikunle Gabriel aka IBK is a graduating student of Management and Accounting Department.0

After long hours of classes and tutorials, I have to still read (who wants to fail?). I refer to myself as a business student. Because even as a student, I have my own tutorial centre, I compiled past questions and solutions  on two courses, and most times I take private tutorials. Time is always a constraint. Lecturers will bombard you with materials on their respective courses.  I move from hostel to academics on average of four times in a day. During the time of political activities, close pals of mine going for the same post will walk up to me. "Ibk, I'm going for this, I'm going for that. " You have to decide on who to support. During breaks,  they will ask at home: "Who is the picture perfect? " 
                  Comics In The Midst Of Academic Rigours
In spite of all the academic rigours students face on campus, we would always have one or two things that amuse us students. In Awo Hall, we were often entertained by the Aro performance. Some hilarious guys could just enter into Awo Cafe and started throwing jibes at the students "jacking" there. On OAU campus, you may be referred to by your friends and course mates as "Shana" or "Iwe Ogba" even when you are still struggling with a course. On several occasions , I'd been to Academics to read, but found it difficult to concentrate, yet when coming back, my course mates I met on the way would still call me Iwe Ogba.
                         My Involvement In Political Activities
On gaining admission, I went to the secondary school I attended to break the news of my admission to my teachers, being a well recognised student in the school. One of them told me:
"Ibikunle, when you get to campus, don't join politics. Campus politics is bloody o, and don't join them in doing  any aluta o. You know you are tall, they can easily spot you."
Sincerely, I was glad OAU politics is not bloody compared to what I've heard about some other schools. I've joined the aluta train right from my day one on campus. I doff my cap for the comrades who fought frantically with their sweat and blood for the peace which OAU students now enjoy. Kudos to the comrades who from time to time defend the rights and interests of students. I have a lot of respect for these guys. 
I wanted to contest for the post of an honourable at the students' union level in my part 2 days, but as fate would have it, the students'union was suspended by the powers that be. In  my penultimate year, I contested for the post of the president in my department, but the best candidate won. My involvement in politics made me meet so many greatness-bound comrades who will forever be in my memory. I also learnt so many lessons politics has in stock to teach its students. I'm glad to have contributed my quota to the redefinition of the campus political terrain. 
                           The wonderful people I Met
In our sojourn in life, we'll come across many people God has chosen to be our companions as we journey on. I must not fail to mention the wonderful personalities I met in my short spell on this campus. Let me start from my wonderful lecturers like Mr. Quadri Lawal, a.k.a. Resolution whom I refer to as 'simple Resolution'(He has the most stupendous personality traits anyone can emulate or desire), Mr. Siyanbade a.k.a. I Can, Dr Monday, Dr. Olasanmi and other lecturers who've had significant impact in my life and career. 
I'll always relish the day I met Falade Adenike, an awesome companion anyone will dream of befriending. Olowu Oladipupo, you're a true friend. Tofunmi, you're a wonderful lady, Abiola, you're awesome, Wahab Akeem a.k.a. Highcomm, you're a rare gem. Omaka Kingsley, you're not just a friend, but also a mentor. I also appreciate The Cognoscentis, Olajide Oreoluwa a.k.a Pretty Priya, Oshun Adebola, Idowu Deborah, Taiwo, Kemi Helen, Esther, Bewaji Omolewa, Akerele Isaac, Emmanuel a.k.a. Pato(Law), Onuche (Law), Bernard P. Daniel,Paulo, Toluano(Phl), Papinx(LGS), Fiwajomi, Tosin, Adebisi, Essien, Funmilola, Pelumi, Rhoda (DSS), Ibidunmoye Decent Ayobami, Fynestboi (PHL), Bridget, Al-Ameen(Foreign Language), Deepeah (Pub Admin), Adefiranye Adenike, Ibukun (Interrel), Mimi, Gbemisola (History), Ife (Chm), E-Dan(Pharmacy),  Oluoma, Emmanuel Faith, Rachael (Econs Edu), Barezzi, Oyinda, Hajia Rukayat, Wandy, Tbamz,Sinuola, Bimbo, Emperor, and every other person who made my campus sojourn memorable. 
                                                            And Finally
I always believe that the school made me. I'm confident to say I'm a product of sound formal and self education. I learnt a whole lot on this campus.To my junior colleagues, I will say: never lose the power of focus; never be a staight-jacketed kind of learners, don't limit yourselves to your field alone. Medical students write good poems. Explore your world. To my graduating course mates and colleagues, see you at the top
As I sign out today, I can gladly say:
Veni vedi vici

Sunmonu Ibikunle Gabriel aka IBK is a graduating student of Management and Accounting Department.

data.post:
As I sign out
"Everybody has a story to tell, a joke to share and a lesson to learn."- Unknown
                                 How The Journey Started
It has always been my childhood dream to attend the prestigious Obafemi Awolowo University, so, when I was offered admission to study Management and Accounting in this great citadel, my joy knew no bound. Although, not until ASUU completed a six-month strike were we called upon to resume as freshers.Upon resumption, we began to do the necessary registrations- faculty registration, departmental registration health centre registration and so on. 
Few days after the necessary registrations, lectures began. As a freshman, I couldn't wait to receive my first lecture- the first lecture we had was on History of Accounting in Acc 101 which was taught by Dr. Mrs Salawu at Law 209. After the lecture that evening, I trudge to my hostel alongside a coursemate, relishing the joy of being an undergraduate. 
                            My Days In Awo Hall
Through out my undergraduate days, I stayed in Awo Hall. Awo Hall is the most popular hall on OAU campus. Its nickname is "castle of great men". Some students refer to it as the capital of OAU. The hall is always a lively place, especially in the evening. The Awo Boyz All-Star never failed to entertain the students with their "Aro"; the political-conscious students did gather beside the notice board at the lower buttery to discuss political issues. Those were the days of Comrade Engels, Ibikunle, who was the students' union president in my part one days, Comrade Juwon, Levuz, Hon.Bright, Ojogbon, Olori, Comrade Azaro, Binzu,  Honourable TY,who later became the students'union president, Immanuel Kant, Hon.IBk. Also some students made funny sounds all around the hostel like barking, bleating, mewing, and crowing, to make people laugh.
Our room was often boisterous with guys arguing about sport, music, academics, politics, the opposite sex and many more. On many occasions, guys from other rooms came to our room to engage us in conversations about different topics. It's difficult to concentrate on reading in the room. If you wanted to read, you would have to pack your books and go to Awo Cafe, Upper Reading Room or better still Academics. In spite of the noise, I sometimes read in the room and my room mates would wonder how I was able to concentrate, but it's a condition I've got myself used to.
In my part one days an amazing incident happened in our room, which still amuses me to this day. It was around 2 a.m. and we were all asleep except for Alfa Shina who was washing his cloth downstairs. The whole drama began when Taiwo Suddenly sprang to his feet as if something had hit or a creature had bitten him. Quadri and Segun who slept beside him also woke up in that instant; the three of them headed for the door but before they got to the door, Modupe(Wandy) who had jumped down from his upper bunk was already there standing still.At that moment also, every other person including me was running  towards the door. I woke up when Daniel stamped on my feet while trying to make off. I was shouting: "Blood of Jesus!", "Blood of Jesus!!". If not for Modupe, a chubby guy who stood by the door motionless, Taiwo or Quadri would have succeeded in opening the door and some of us would have jumped down from our floor- the second floor- or probably rushed down through the staircase.
Soon after, we all came back to our senses and realised that there was no danger around; we didn't see any sign of fire, no strange movement or sound to make us think a snake had crept in, we asked Taiwo what he saw that made him spring to his feet in the first place, and he couldn't say anything. data.post:
Uncaged Bird
Today, I had the instinct
Of an uncaged bird
I felt what an uncaged bird feels:
The feeling that I can fly
And the freedom to fly as I wish
So I decided to fly around the world
To explore its fulness
Not leaving out its emptiness
To explore its glamour
Without bias to its squalor
In the course of my traverse
I landed in the house of the poor
I beheld their pursuit of riches
I landed in the house of the cynics
I caught a full glimpse of their pessimism
I landed in the house of the oppressed
I saw their crave for freedom
I landed in the house of the greedy
I heard their never-ending melody
of "We want some more."

IBk

Beauty in the heart of darkness

Walking in the crowd
Clothed in a shroud
Shouting all aloud
Not minding if it's allowed
Wanting to be proud
Never to be cowed

It's beauty in the heart of darkness
Swimming in the pool of gladness
Who can rid it of its sadness?
Or who can cure it of its madness?
When faced with barrenness

Ever craving for sweet melody
Never praying for a tragedy
Seeking endlessly a remedy
To all forms of malady

data.post:
Many Thoughts

How do I express
The many thoughts
That run in my mind
Like a river:
The thought of happiness
Each time I remember
The evanescence of our life
The thought of laughter
Each time I remember the folly of man
The thought of love
Each time I remember
The ones I love
The thought of forgiveness
Each time I remember
Those that offend me
The thought of guilt
Each time I remember
Those that I offend
The thought of gratitude
Each time I remember
Those with benevolent hearts
Should I write it on the sand
Away will the wind blow it
Should I write it on water
No sooner will I do
Than it will flow away
Maybe then I write beautiful poems
For the whole world to read

Written by Sunmonu Ibikunle Gabriel aka IBK
